 a_1 \cdot c_{2005} \cdot 1^{2005} & + & a_2 \cdot c_2 \cdot 2^{2005} & + & a_3 \cdot c_{2005} \cdot 3^{2005} & + & \dotsb & + & a_{2005} \cdot c_{2005} \cdot 2005^{2005} & = & c_{2005}. \end{array} \]Note that the terms in the $k$th column add up to $p(k).$  Thus, \[a_1 p(1) + a_2 p(2) + a_3 p(3) + \dots + a_{2005} p(2005) = c_{2005}.\]Note that this holds for any constants $c_1,$ $c_2,$ $\dots,$ $c_{2005}$ we choose.
 Since we want $a_1,$ we choose the coefficients $c_i$ so that all of the terms in the equation above disappear, except for $a_1 p(1).$  We can achieve this by setting \[p(x) = x(x - 2)(x - 3) \dotsm (x - 2005).\]Then $p(1) = 2004!$ and $p(k) = 0$ for $k = 2,$, 3, $\dots,$ 2005, so
 \[2004! \cdot a_1 = 1.\]Hence, $a_1 = \boxed{\frac{1}{2004! }}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1..2005} \<longrightarrow> f n = (a n) * (n powr n)"
and h1 : "sum f {1..2005} = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1..2004} \<longrightarrow> f n = (a n) * (n powr (n+1))"
and h3 : "sum f {1..2004} = 0"
and h4 : "f 2005 = a 2005 * (2005 powr 2005) = 1"
shows  "a 1 = 1 / fact 2004"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a function $f(n) = a(n) * n^n$ for all $n$ in the set {1, 2, ..., 2005}. The sum of $f(n)$ for all $n$ in the set {1, 2, ..., 2005} is 0. Also, for all $n$ in the set {1, 2, ..., 2004}, $f(n) = a(n) * n^{n+1}$, and the sum of $f(n)$ for all $n$ in the set {1, 2, ..., 2004} is also 0. Given that $f(2005) = a(2005) * 2005^{2005} = 1$, find the value of $a(1)$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{2004!}$.
